name: IDIOPHONES
def: The substance of the instrument itself, owing to its solidity and elasticity, yields the sounds, without requiring stretched membranes or strings

subclasses.name: Struck idiophones
subclasses.def: The instrument is made to vibrate by being struck upon

subclasses.name: Idiophones struck directly
subclasses.def: The player himself executes the movement of striking; whether by mechanical intermediate devices, beaters, keyboards, or by pulling ropes, etc., is immaterial; it is definitive that the player can apply clearly defined individual strokes and that the instrument itself is equipped for this kind of percussion

subclasses.name: Concussion idiophones or clappers
subclasses.def: Two or more complementary sonorous parts are struck against each other

subclasses.name: Concussion vessels or vessel clappers
subclasses.def: Even a slight hollow in the surface of a board counts as a vessel

subclasses.name: Castanets
subclasses.def: Vessel clappers, either natural, or artificially hollowed out

subclasses.name: Cymbals
subclasses.def: Vessel clappers with everted rim

subclasses.name: Percussion idiophones
subclasses.def: The instrument is struck either with a non-sonorous object (hand, stick, striker) or against a non-sonorous object (human body, the ground)

subclasses.name: (Individual) percussion sticks
subclasses.ex: Japan, Annam, Balkans; also the triangle

subclasses.name: Sets of percussion sticks
subclasses.def: Several percussion sticks of different pitch are combined to form a single instrument
subclasses.ex: All xylophones, as long as their sounding components are not in two different planes

subclasses.name: Gongs
subclasses.def: The vibration is strongest near the vertex

subclasses.name: (Individual) gongs
subclasses.ex: S. and E. Asia; including the so-called metal drums, or rather kettle-gongs

subclasses.name: Bells
subclasses.def: The vibration is weakest near the vertex

subclasses.name: Resting bells
subclasses.def: The cup is placed on the palm of the hand or on a cushion; its mouth faces upwards

subclasses.name: Suspended bells
subclasses.def: The bell is suspended from the apex

subclasses.name: Suspended bells struck from the outside
subclasses.def: No striker is attached inside the bell, there being a separate beater

subclasses.name: Clapper bells
subclasses.def: A striker (clapper) is attached inside the bell

subclasses.name: Sets of resting bells
subclasses.def: The cup is placed on the palm of the hand or on a cushion; its mouth faces upwards

subclasses.name: Sets of suspended bells
subclasses.def: The bell is suspended from the apex

subclasses.name: Sets of suspended bells struck from the outside
subclasses.def: No striker is attached inside the bell, there being a separate beater

subclasses.name: Sets of clapper bells
subclasses.def: A striker (clapper) is attached inside the bell

subclasses.name: Indirectly struck idiophones
subclasses.def: The player himself does not go through the movement of striking; percussion results indirectly through some other movement by the player. The intention of the instrument is to yield clusters of sounds or noises, and not to let individual strokes be perceived

subclasses.name: Shaken idiophones or rattles
subclasses.def: The player executes a shaking motion

subclasses.name: Suspension rattles
subclasses.def: Perforated idiophones are mounted together, and shaken to strike against each other

subclasses.name: Strung rattles
subclasses.def: Rattling objects are strung in rows on a cord

subclasses.name: Stick rattles
subclasses.def: Rattling objects are strung on a bar (or ring)

subclasses.name: Frame rattles
subclasses.def: Rattling objects are attached to a carrier against which they strike

subclasses.name: Pendant rattles
subclasses.def: Rattling objects are hung from a frame

subclasses.name: Sliding rattles
subclasses.def: Non-sonorous objects slide to and fro in the slots of the sonorous object wo that the latter is made to vibrate; or sonorous objects slide to and fro in the slots of a non-sonorous object, to be set in vibration by the impacts

subclasses.name: Vessel rattles
subclasses.def: rattling objects enclosed in a vessel strike against each other or against the walls of the vessel, or usually against both. NB The Benue gourd rattles with handle, in which the rattling objects, instead of being enclosed, are knotted into a net slipped over the outer surface, count as a variety of vessel rate
subclasses.ex: Fruit shells with seeds, 'pellet beels' enclosing loose percussion pellets

subclasses.name: Scraped idiophones
subclasses.def: The player causes a scraping movement directly or indirectly: a non-sonorous object moves along the notched surface of a sonorous object, to be alternately lifted off the teeth and flicked against them; or an elastic sonorous object moves along the surface of a notched non-sonorous object to cause a series of impacts. This group must not be confused with that of friction idiophones

subclasses.name: Scraped sticks
subclasses.def: A notched stick is scraped with a little stick

subclasses.name: Scraped sticks without resonator
subclasses.ex: S. America, India (notched musical bow), Congo

subclasses.name: Scraped vessels
subclasses.def: The corrugated surface of a vessel is scraped

subclasses.name: Scraped wheels or cog rattles
subclasses.def: A cog wheel, whose axle serves as the handle, and a tongue fixed in a frame which is free to turn on the handle; when whirled, the tongue strikes the teeth of the wheel one after nother

subclasses.name: Split idiophones
subclasses.def: Instruments in the shape of two springy arms connected at one end and touching at the other: the arms are forced apart by a little stick, to jingle or vibrate on recoil

subclasses.name: Plucked idiophones
subclasses.def: Lamellae, i.e. elastic plaques, fixed at one end, are flexed and then released to return to their position of rest

subclasses.name: in the form of a frame
subclasses.def: The lamella vibrates within a frame or hoop

subclasses.name: Clack idiophones (cricri)
subclasses.def: The lamella is carved in the surface of a fruit shell, which serves as a resonator

subclasses.name: Guimbardes (Jew's harps)
subclasses.def: The lamella is mounted in a rod or plaque-shaped frame and depends on the player's mouth cavity for resonance

subclasses.name: Idioglot guimbardes
subclasses.def: The lamella is carved in the frame itself, its base remaining joined to the frame

subclasses.name: Heteroglot guimbardes
subclasses.def: A lamella is attached to a frame

subclasses.name: Sets of heteroglot guimbardes
subclasses.def: Several heteroglot guimbardes of different pitches are combined to form a single instrument

subclasses.name: in board or comb-form
subclasses.def: The lamellae are tied to a board or cut out from a board like the teeth of a comb

subclasses.name: without resonator
subclasses.ex: All sansas on a plain board

subclasses.name: with resonator
subclasses.ex: All sansas with a box or bowl below the board

subclasses.name: with cut-out lamellae (musical boxes)
subclasses.def: Pins on a cylinder pluck the lamellae

subclasses.name: Friction idiophones
subclasses.def: The instrument is made to vibrate by friction

subclasses.name: with direct friction
subclasses.def: The sticks themselves are rubbed

subclasses.name: with indirect friction
subclasses.def: The sticks are connected with others which are rubbed and, by transmitting their longitudinal vibrations, stimulate transverse vibration in the former

subclasses.name: Blown idiophones
subclasses.def: the instrument is made to vibrate by being blown upon

name: MEMBRANOPHONES
def: The sound is excited by tightly stretched membranes

subclasses.name: Struck drums
subclasses.def: The membranes are struck

subclasses.name: Drums struck directly
subclasses.def: The player himself executes the movement of striking; this includes striking by any intermediate devices, such as beaters, keyboards, etc; drums that are shaken are excluded

subclasses.name: Kettledrums (timpani)
subclasses.def: The body is bowl- or dish-shaped

subclasses.name: Sets of kettledrums
subclasses.ex: W. Asian permanently joined pairs of kettledrums

subclasses.name: Tubular drums
subclasses.def: The body is tubular

subclasses.name: Cylindrical drums
subclasses.def: The diameter is the same at the middle and the ends; whether or not the ends taper or have projecting discs is immaterial

subclasses.name: Single-skin cylindrical drums
subclasses.def: The drum has only one usable membrane. In some African drums a second skin forms part of the lacing device and is not used for beating, and hence does not count as a membrane in the present sense

subclasses.name: Open cylindrical drums
subclasses.def: The end opposite from the membrane is open

subclasses.name: Closed cylindrical drums
subclasses.def: The end opposite from the membrane is closed

subclasses.name: Double-skin cylindrical drums
subclasses.def: The drum has two usable membranes

subclasses.name: Barrel-shaped drums
subclasses.def: the diameter is larger at the middle than at the ends; the body is curvilinear

subclasses.name: Single-skin barrel-shaped drums
subclasses.def: The drum has only one usable membrane

subclasses.name: Open barrel-shaped drums
subclasses.def: The end opposite from the membrane is open

subclasses.name: Closed barrel-shaped drums
subclasses.def: The end opposite from the membrane is closed

subclasses.name: Double-skin barrel-shaped drums
subclasses.def: The drum has two usable membranes

subclasses.name: Double-conical drums
subclasses.def: The diameter is larger at the middle than at the ends; the body is rectilinear with angular profile

subclasses.name: Hourglass-shaped drums
subclasses.def: The diameter is smaller at the middle than at the ends

subclasses.name: Single-skin Hourglass-shaped drums
subclasses.def: The drum has only one usable membrane

subclasses.name: Open Hourglass-shaped drums
subclasses.def: The end opposite from the membrane is open

subclasses.name: Closed Hourglass-shaped drums
subclasses.def: The end opposite from the membrane is closed

subclasses.name: Double-skin Hourglass-shaped drums
subclasses.def: The drum has two usable membranes

subclasses.name: Conical drums
subclasses.def: The diameters at the ends differ considerable (minor departures from conicity, inevitably met, are disregarded here)

subclasses.name: Single-skin conical drums
subclasses.def: The drum has only one usable membrane

subclasses.name: Open conical drums
subclasses.def: The end opposite from the membrane is open

subclasses.name: Closed conical drums
subclasses.def: The end opposite from the membrane is closed

subclasses.name: Double-skin conical drums
subclasses.def: The drum has two usable membranes

subclasses.name: Goblet-shaped drums
subclasses.def: The body consists of a main section which is either cup-shaped or cylindrical, and a slender stem; borderline cases of this basic design, like those occurring notably in Indonesia, do not affect the identification, so long as a cylindrical form is not in fact reached

subclasses.name: Single-skin goblet-shaped drums
subclasses.def: The drum has only one usable membrane

subclasses.name: Open goblet-shaped drums
subclasses.def: The end opposite from the membrane is open

subclasses.name: Closed goblet-shaped drums
subclasses.def: The end opposite from the membrane is closed

subclasses.name: Double-skin goblet-shaped drums
subclasses.def: The drum has two usable membranes

subclasses.name: Frame drums
subclasses.def: The depth of the body does not exceed the radius of the membrane; NB the European side drum, even in its most shallow form, is a development from the long cylindrical drum and hence is not included among frame drums

subclasses.name: Frame drum with handle
subclasses.def: A stick is attached to the frame in line with its diameter

subclasses.name: Rattle drums
subclasses.def: The drum is shaken; percussion is by impact of pendent or enclosed pellets, or similar objects

subclasses.name: Kettledrums
subclasses.def: The body is bowl- or dish-shaped

subclasses.name: Tubular drums
subclasses.def: The body is tubular

subclasses.name: Cylindrical drums
subclasses.def: The diameter is the same at the middle and the ends; whether or not the ends taper or have projecting discs is immaterial

subclasses.name: Single-skin cylindrical drums
subclasses.def: The drum has only one usable membrane. In some African drums a second skin forms part of the lacing device and is not used for beating, and hence does not count as a membrane in the present sense

subclasses.name: Open cylindrical drums
subclasses.def: The end opposite from the membrane is open

subclasses.name: Closed cylindrical drums
subclasses.def: The end opposite from the membrane is closed

subclasses.name: Double-skin cylindrical drums
subclasses.def: The drum has two usable membranes

subclasses.name: Barrel-shaped drums
subclasses.def: The diameter is larger at the middle than at the ends; the body is curvilinear

subclasses.name: Single-skin barrel-shaped drums
subclasses.def: The drum has only one usable membrane

subclasses.name: Open barrel-shaped drums
subclasses.def: the end opposite from the membrane is open

subclasses.name: Closed barrel-shaped drums
subclasses.def: The end opposite from the membrane is closed

subclasses.name: Double-skin barrel-shaped drums
subclasses.def: The drum has two usable membranes

subclasses.name: Double-conical drums
subclasses.def: The diameter is larger at the middle than at the ends; the body is rectilinear with angular profile

subclasses.name: Hourglass-shaped drums
subclasses.def: The diameter is smaller at the middle than at the ends

subclasses.name: Single-skin Hourglass-shaped drums
subclasses.def: The drum has only one usable membrane

subclasses.name: Open Hourglass-shaped drums
subclasses.def: The end opposite from the membrane is open

subclasses.name: Closed Hourglass-shaped drums
subclasses.def: The end opposite from the membrane is closed

subclasses.name: Double-skin Hourglass-shaped drums
subclasses.def: The drum has two usable membranes

subclasses.name: Conical drums
subclasses.def: The diameters at the ends differ considerable (minor departures from conicity, inevitably met, are disregarded here)

subclasses.name: Single-skin conical drums
subclasses.def: The drum has only one usable membrane

subclasses.name: Open conical drums
subclasses.def: The end opposite from the membrane is open

subclasses.name: Closed conical drums
subclasses.def: The end opposite from the membrane is closed

subclasses.name: Double-skin conical drums
subclasses.def: The drum has two usable membranes

subclasses.name: Goblet-shaped drums
subclasses.def: The body consists of a main section which is either cup-shaped or cylindrical, and a slender stem

subclasses.name: Single-skin goblet-shaped drums
subclasses.def: The drum has only one usable membrane

subclasses.name: Open goblet-shaped drums
subclasses.def: The end opposite from the membrane is open

subclasses.name: Closed goblet-shaped drums
subclasses.def: The end opposite from the membrane is closed

subclasses.name: Double-skin goblet-shaped drums
subclasses.def: The drum has two usable membranes

subclasses.name: Frame drums
subclasses.def: The depth of the body does not exceed the radius of the membrane

subclasses.name: Frame drum with handle
subclasses.def: A stick is attached to the frame in line with its diameter

subclasses.name: Plucked drums
subclasses.def: A string is knotted below the centre of the membrane; when the string is plucked, its vibrations are transmitted to the membrane

subclasses.name: Friction drums
subclasses.def: The membrane is made to vibrate by friction

subclasses.name: Friction drums with stick
subclasses.def: A stick in contact with the membrane is either itself rubbed, or is employed to rub the membrane

subclasses.name: with inserted stick
subclasses.def: The stick passes through a hole in the membrane

subclasses.name: Friction drums with fixed stick
subclasses.def: The stick cannot be moved; the stick alone is subjected to friction by rubbing

subclasses.name: Friction drums with semi-fixed stick
subclasses.def: The stick is movable to a sufficient extent to rub the membrane when it is itself rubbed by the hand

subclasses.name: Friction drums with free stick
subclasses.def: The stick can be moved freely; it is not itself rubbed, but is employed to rub the membrane

subclasses.name: with tied stick
subclasses.def: The stick is tied to the membrane in an upright position

subclasses.name: Friction drum with cord
subclasses.def: a cord, attached to the membrane, is rubbed

subclasses.name: Stationary friction drum with cord
subclasses.def: The drum is held stationary

subclasses.name: Single-skin stationary drums with friction cord
Double-skin stationary drums with friction cord
Friction drum with whirling stick
subclasses.def: The drum is whirled on a cord which rubs on a [resined] notch in the holding stick

subclasses.name: Hand friction drums
subclasses.def: The membrane is rubbed by the hand

subclasses.name: Singing membranes (Kazoos)
subclasses.def: The membrane is made to vibrate by speaking or singing into it; the membrane does not yield a note of its own but merely modifies the voice

subclasses.name: Free kazoos
subclasses.def: The membrane is incited directly, without the wind first passing through a chamber

subclasses.name: Tube or vessel-kazoos
subclasses.def: The membrane is placed inside a tube or box
subclasses.ex: Africa; while also, E. Asian flutes with a lateral hole sealed by a membrane, exhibit an adulteration with the principle of the tube kazoo

subclasses.name: cord-(ribbon-) bracing
subclasses.def: The cords are stretched from membrane to membrane or arranged in form of a net, without employing any of the devices described below

subclasses.name: with tension ligature
subclasses.def: Cross ribbons or cords are tied round the middle of the lacing to increase its tension

subclasses.name: with tension loops
subclasses.def: The cords are laced in a zigzat; every pair of strings is caught together with a small ring or loop

subclasses.name: with wedge-bracing
subclasses.def: Wedges are inserted between the wall of the drum and the cords of the lacing; by adjusting the position of the wedges it is possible to control the tension

subclasses.name: cord-and-hide bracing
subclasses.def: The cords are laced at the lower end to a non-sonorous piece of hide

subclasses.name: with tension ligature
subclasses.def: Cross ribbons or cords are tied round the middle of the lacing to increase its tension

subclasses.name: with tension loops
subclasses.def: The cords are laced in a zigzat; every pair of strings is caught together with a small ring or loop

subclasses.name: with wedge-bracing
subclasses.def: Wedges are inserted between the wall of the drum and the cords of the lacing; by adjusting the position of the wedges it is possible to control the tension

subclasses.name: cord-and-board bracing
subclasses.def: The cords are laced to an auxiliary board

subclasses.name: with tension ligature
subclasses.def: Cross ribbons or cords are tied round the middle of the lacing to increase its tension

subclasses.name: with tension loops
subclasses.def: The cords are laced in a zigzat; every pair of strings is caught together with a small ring or loop

subclasses.name: with wedge-bracing
subclasses.def: Wedges are inserted between the wall of the drum and the cords of the lacing; by adjusting the position of the wedges it is possible to control the tension

subclasses.name: cord-and-flange bracing
subclasses.def: The cords are laced at the lower end to a flange carved from the solid

subclasses.name: with tension ligature
subclasses.def: Cross ribbons or cords are tied round the middle of the lacing to increase its tension

subclasses.name: with tension loops
subclasses.def: The cords are laced in a zigzat; every pair of strings is caught together with a small ring or loop

subclasses.name: with wedge-bracing
subclasses.def: Wedges are inserted between the wall of the drum and the cords of the lacing; by adjusting the position of the wedges it is possible to control the tension

subclasses.name: cord-and-belt bracing
subclasses.def: The cords are laced at the lower end to a belt of different material

subclasses.name: with tension ligature
subclasses.def: Cross ribbons or cords are tied round the middle of the lacing to increase its tension

subclasses.name: with tension loops
subclasses.def: The cords are laced in a zigzat; every pair of strings is caught together with a small ring or loop

subclasses.name: with wedge-bracing
subclasses.def: Wedges are inserted between the wall of the drum and the cords of the lacing; by adjusting the position of the wedges it is possible to control the tension

subclasses.name: cord-and-peg bracing
subclasses.def: The cords are laced at the lower end to pegs stuck into the wall of the drum

subclasses.name: with tension ligature
subclasses.def: Cross ribbons or cords are tied round the middle of the lacing to increase its tension

subclasses.name: with tension loops
subclasses.def: The cords are laced in a zigzat; every pair of strings is caught together with a small ring or loop

subclasses.name: with wedge-bracing
subclasses.def: Wedges are inserted between the wall of the drum and the cords of the lacing; by adjusting the position of the wedges it is possible to control the tension

suffixes.name: with membrane lapped on
suffixes.def: A ring is slipped over the edge of the membrane

subclasses.name: with membrane lapped on by ring of cord
with membrane lapped on by a hoop

name: CHORDOPHONES
def: One or more strings are stretched between fixed points

subclasses.name: Simple chordophones or zithers
subclasses.def: The instrument consists solely of a string bearer, or of a string bearer with a resonator which is not integral and can be detached without destroying the sound-producing apparatus

subclasses.name: Bar zithers
subclasses.def: The string bearer is bar-shaped; it may be a board placed edgewise

subclasses.name: Musical bows
subclasses.def: The string bearer is flexible (and curved)

subclasses.name: Idiochord musical bows
subclasses.def: The string is cut from the bark of the cane, remaining attached at each end

subclasses.name: Mono-idiochord musical bows
subclasses.def: The bow has one idiochord string only

subclasses.name: Poly-idiochord musical bows or harp-bows
subclasses.def: The bow has several idiochord strings which pass over a toothed stick or bridge

subclasses.name: Heterochord musical bows
subclasses.def: The string is of separate material from the bearer

subclasses.name: Mono-heterochord musical bows
subclasses.def: The bow has one heterochord string only

subclasses.name: without resonator
subclasses.def: NB If a separate, unattached resonator is used, the specimen belongs to 311.121.21. The human mouth is not to be taken into account as a resonator

subclasses.name: Poly-heterochord musical bows
subclasses.def: The bow has several heterochord strings

subclasses.name: Stick zithers
subclasses.def: The string carrier is rigid

subclasses.name: Musical bow cum stick
subclasses.def: The string bearer has one flexible, curved end. NB Stick zithers with both ends flexible and curved, like the Basuto bow, are counted as musical bows

subclasses.name: (True) stick zithers
subclasses.def: NB Round sticks which happen to be hollow by chance do not belong to this account of the tube zithers, but are round-bar zithers; however, instruments in which a tubular cavity is employed as a true resonator, like the modern Mexican harpa, are tube zithers

subclasses.name: Tube zithers
subclasses.def: The string bearer is a vaulted surface

subclasses.name: Whole-tube zithers
subclasses.def: The string carrier is a complete tube

subclasses.name: with extra resonator
subclasses.def: An internode length of bamboo is placed inside a palm leaf tied in the shape of a bowl

subclasses.name: Half-tube zithers
subclasses.def: The strings are stretched along the convex surface of a gutter

subclasses.name: Raft zithers
subclasses.def: The string bearer is composed of canes tied together in the manner of a raft

subclasses.name: Board zithers
subclasses.def: The string bearer is a board; the ground too is to be counted as such

subclasses.name: True board zithers
subclasses.def: The plane of the strings is parallel with that of the string bearer

subclasses.name: with resonator bowl
subclasses.def: The resonator is a fruit shell or similar object, or an artificially carved equivalent

subclasses.name: with resonator box (box zither)
subclasses.def: The resonator is made from slats

subclasses.name: Board zither variations
subclasses.def: The plane of the strings is at right angles to the string bearer

subclasses.name: Ground zithers
subclasses.def: The ground is the string bearer; there is only one string

subclasses.name: Harp zithers
subclasses.def: A board serves as string bearer; there are several strings and a notched bridge

subclasses.name: Trough zithers
subclasses.def: The strings are stretched across the mouth of a trough

subclasses.name: with resonator
subclasses.def: The trough has a gourd or a similar object attached to it

subclasses.name: Frame zithers
subclasses.def: The strings are stretched across an open frame

subclasses.name: Composite chordophones
subclasses.def: A string bearer and a resonator are organically united and cannot be separated without destroying the instrument

subclasses.name: Lutes
subclasses.def: The plane of the strings runs parallel with the sound-table

subclasses.name: Bow lutes [pluriarcs]
subclasses.def: Each string has its own flexible carrier

subclasses.name: Yoke lutes or lyres
subclasses.def: The strings are attached to a yoke which lies in the same plane as the sound-table and consists of two arms and a cross-bar

subclasses.name: Bowl lyres
subclasses.def: A natural or carved-out bowl serves as the resonator

subclasses.name: Box lyres
subclasses.def: A built-up wooden box serves as the resonator

subclasses.name: Handle lutes
subclasses.def: The string bearer is a plain handle. Subsidiary necks, as e.g. in the Indian prasarini vina are disregarded, as are also lutes with strings distributed over several necks, like the harpolyre, and those like the Lyre-guitars, in which the yoke is merely ornamental

subclasses.name: Spike lutes
subclasses.def: The handle passes diametrically through the resonator

subclasses.name: Spike bowl lutes
subclasses.def: The resonator consists of a natural or carved-out bowl

subclasses.name: Spike box lutes or spike guitars
subclasses.def: The resonator is built up from wood

subclasses.name: Spike tube lutes
subclasses.def: The handle passes diametrically through the walls of a tube

subclasses.name: Necked lutes
subclasses.def: The handle is attached to or carved from the resonator, like a neck

subclasses.name: Necked box lutes or necked guitars
Harps
subclasses.def: The plane of the strings lies at right angles to the sound-table; a line joining the lower ends of the strings would point towards the neck

subclasses.name: Open harps
subclasses.def: The harp has no pillar

subclasses.name: Arched harps
subclasses.def: The neck curves away from the resonator

subclasses.name: Angular harps
subclasses.def: The neck makes a sharp angle with the resonator

subclasses.name: Frame harps
subclasses.def: The harp has a pillar

subclasses.name: with the strings in one plane
subclasses.ex: Most of the older chromatic harps

subclasses.name: with the strings in two planes crossing one another
with manual action
subclasses.def: The tuning can be altered by hand-levers

subclasses.name: with pedal action
subclasses.def: The tuning can be altered by pedals

subclasses.name: Harp-lutes
subclasses.def: The plane of the strings lies at right angles to the sound-table; a line joining the lower ends of the strings would be perpendicular to the neck. Notched bridge

name: AEROPHONES
def: The air itself is the vibrator in the primary sense

subclasses.name: Free aerophones
subclasses.def: The vibrating air is not confined by the instrument

subclasses.name: Displacement free aerophones
subclasses.def: The air stream meets a sharp edge,or a sharp edge is moved through the air. In either case, according to more recent views, a periodic displacement of air occurs to alternate flanks of the edge

subclasses.name: Interruptive free aerophones
subclasses.def: The air stream is interrupted periodically

subclasses.name: Idiophonic interruptive aerophones or reeds
subclasses.def: The air stream is directed against a lamella, setting it in periodic vibration to interrupt the stream intermittently. In this group also belong reeds with a 'cover', i.e. a tube in which the air vibrates only in a secondary sense, not producing the sound but simply adding roundness and timbre to the sound made by the reed's vibration; generally recognizable by the absence of fingerholes

subclasses.name: Concussion reeds
subclasses.def: Two lamellae make a gap which closes periodically during their vibration

subclasses.name: Percussion reeds
subclasses.def: A single lamella strikes against a frame

subclasses.name: Sets of percussion reeds
subclasses.def: The earlier reed stops of organs

subclasses.name: Free reeds
subclasses.def: The lamella vibrates through a closely fitting slot

subclasses.name: Sets of free reeds
subclasses.def: NB In instruments like the Chinese sheng the fingerholes do not serve to modify the pitch and are therefore not equivalent to the fingerholes of other pipes

subclasses.name: Ribbon reeds
subclasses.def: The air stream is directed against the edge of a stretched band or ribbon. The acoustics of this process has not yet been studied

subclasses.name: Non-idiophonic interruptive instruments
subclasses.def: The interruptive agent is not a reed

subclasses.name: Rotating aerophones
subclasses.def: The interruptive agent rotates in its own plane

subclasses.name: Whirling aerophones
subclasses.def: The interruptive agent turns on its axis

subclasses.name: Plosive aerophones
subclasses.def: The air is made to vibrate by a single density stimulus condensation shock

subclasses.name: Wind instruments proper
subclasses.def: The vibrating air is confined whithin the instrument itself

subclasses.name: Edge instruments or flutes
subclasses.def: A narrow stream of air is directed against an edge

subclasses.name: Flutes without duct
subclasses.def: The player himself creates a ribbon-shaped stream of air with his lips

subclasses.name: End blown flutes
subclasses.def: The player blows against the sharp rim at the upper open end of a tube

subclasses.name: Open single end-blown flutes
subclasses.def: The lower end of the flute is open

subclasses.name: Stopped single end-blown flutes
subclasses.def: The lower end of the flute is closed

subclasses.name: Sets of end-blown flutes or panpipes
subclasses.def: Several end-blown flutes of different pitch are combined to form a single instrument

subclasses.name: Open (raft) panpipes
subclasses.def: The pipes are tied together in the form of a board, or they are made by drilling tubes in a board

subclasses.name: Open bundle (pan-) pipes
subclasses.def: The pipes are tied together in a round bundle
subclasses.ex: Solomon Is., New Britain, New Ireland, Admiralty Is.

subclasses.name: Side-blown flutes
subclasses.def: The player blows against the sharp rim of a hole in the side of the tube

subclasses.name: with fingerholes
subclasses.def: European flute

subclasses.name: Partly-stopped side-blown flutes
subclasses.def: The lower end of the tube is a natural node of the pipe pierced by a small hole

subclasses.name: with adjustable stopped lower end (piston flutes)
Vessel flutes (without distinct beak)
subclasses.def: The body of the pipe is not tubular but vessel-shaped

subclasses.name: Flutes with duct or duct flutes
subclasses.def: A narrow duct directs the air stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice

subclasses.name: Flutes with external duct
subclasses.def: The duct is outside the wall of the flute; this group includes flutes with the duct chamfered in the wall under a ring-like sleeve and other similar arrangements

subclasses.name: Sets of flutes with external duct
Flutes with internal duct
subclasses.def: The duct is inside the tube. This group includes flutes with the duct formed by an internal baffle (natural node, block of resin) and an exterior tied-on cover (cane, wood, hide)

subclasses.name: Sets of flutes with internal duct
Sets of open flutes with internal duct
without fingerholes
subclasses.ex: Open flue stops of the organ

subclasses.name: Sets of partly-stopped flutes with internal duct
Sets of stopped flutes with internal duct
subclasses.ex: Stopped flue stops of the organ

subclasses.name: Reedpipes
subclasses.def: The air stream has, through means of two lamella placed at the head of the instrument, intermittent access to the column of air which is to be made to vibrate

subclasses.name: Oboes
subclasses.def: The pipe has a [double] reed of concussion lamellae (usually a flattened stem)

subclasses.name: with conical bore
subclasses.def: India

subclasses.name: Clarinets
subclasses.def: The pipe has a [single] 'reed' consisting of a percussion lamella

subclasses.name: Reedpipes with free reeds
subclasses.def: The reed vibrates through [at] a closely fitted frame. There must be fingerholes, otherwise the instrument belongs to the free reeds 412.13

subclasses.name: Trumpets
subclasses.def: The air-stream passes through the player's vibrating lips, so gaining intermittant access to the air column which is to be made to vibrate

subclasses.name: Natural trumpets
subclasses.def: Without extra devices to alter pitch

subclasses.name: Conches
subclasses.def: A conch shell serves as trumpet

subclasses.name: End-blown trumpets
subclasses.def: The mouth-hole faces the axis of the trumpet

subclasses.name: End-blown straight trumpets
subclasses.def: The tube is neither curved nor folded

subclasses.name: End-blown horns
subclasses.def: The tube is curved or folded

subclasses.name: Side-blown trumpets
subclasses.def: The embouchure is in the side of the tube

subclasses.name: Chromatic trumpets
subclasses.def: With extra devices to modify the pitch

subclasses.name: Slide trumpets
subclasses.def: The tube can be lengthened by extending a telescopic section of the instrument

subclasses.name: Trumpets with valves
subclasses.def: The tube is lengthened or shortened by connecting or disconnecting auxiliary lengths of tube

subclasses.name: Valve bugles
subclasses.def: The tube is conical throughout

subclasses.name: Valve horns
subclasses.def: The tube is predominantly conical

subclasses.name: Valve trumpets
subclasses.def: The tube is predominantly cylindrical

subclasses.name: with Bandmechanik [presumably a perforated roll or ribbon]
